_prev_prog_3.Description:
Lucite operates all areas of its manufacturing facilities with the same process safety program elements, including processes that are not covered by the RMP prevention program requirements. As such everything listed in this prevention program applies to all Lucite process areas.



The oleum storage tanks are part of the SAR Process.  Two identical tanks are used to store oleum for further use in another process.  The storage tanks are part of the area's PSM Program.  The tanks are carbon steel and protected by remote cut-offs and redundant level systems.  The tanks are externally and internally inspected on a regular basis according to the API Guidelines.  Personnel are trained in the operation of the storage tanks.  Maintenance PM schedules are active on the two storage tanks.

MITSUBISHI CHEMICAL METHACRYLATES SAFETY, HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY



We will drive continuous improvement in safety, health and environmental performance through our SHE Excellence program.



In particular:



- Our actions will support the belief that all injuries, illnesses and incidents are preventable

- We will comply with all applicable laws, regulations and the industry's Responsible Care ®ulations; initiative and take any additional measures considered necessary

- The SHE performance of contractors is an integral part of Mitsubishi Chemical's performance and will be managed to equivalent standards

- Our stewardship of SHE matters will be such that the community at large considers Mitsubishi Chemical a good neighbor

- We will pursue continuous improvement in our SHE performance and maximize our progress through the involvement of all employees

- All employees are responsible for the prevention of injuries, illnesses and environmental incidents. Accepting that responsibility is a condition of employment

- Line supervision will be accountable for SHE results and for the performance of their employees

- Employees will be thoroughly trained to work safely and to anticipate and prevent SHE incidents

- Audits will be conducted at all levels of the organization to evaluate work practices and the effectiveness of the SHE program

- All deficiencies will be corrected within an appropriate time frame

- All incidents, whether injury occurs or not, will be thoroughly investigated to identify root causes and prevent recurrence.





MITSUBISHI CHEMICAL MEMPHIS FITE ROAD PLANT



The Mitsubishi Chemical Memphis Methacryaltes Plant is a continuous chemical manufacturing facility that uses chemicals, including Oleum, to produce Methyl Methacrylate (MMA). MMA is the major building block for a wide range of acrylic applications that are found in industries worldwide including: automotive, construction, retail and electronics. 

The Mitsubishi Chemical Proce

ss Safety Management Program defines the accidental release prevention and emergency response policies as required by the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and corporate Mitsubishi Chemical Methacrylates SHE standards. All policies meet the most stringent requirements of all applicable standards and regulations. 





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



In the last five years, the Mitsubishi Chemical Memphis Methacrylates Plant has not experienced any accidental releases of RMP regulated chemicals, specifically Oleum, which have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 





MITSUBISHI CHEMICAL ACCIDENT PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Mitsubishi Chemical US Regional Manufacturing Director, has overall accountability for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner. This accountability includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program. To ensure that our program is appropriately applied and maintained, Manufacturing Director has delegated to a number of defined positions specific responsibilities in relation to the development, maintenance, implementation, and assurance of compliance with all requirements.  



These positions include:



The Responsible Site Executive - also known as the Site Manager, ensures adequate site resource and support in order to comply with all regulatory and corporate requirements

The Regional EHS Manager - oversees the systems and procedures for implementation of Occupational Safety, Health, and Environmental programs

The Regional Technology Director - oversees the development of technical documentation and analysis to identify and manage process hazards

The PSM Engineer - oversees the systems and procedures for implementation of the PSM and the risk man

agement programs 

The Responsible Operating Manager - ensures local operating procedures address requirements and audits for compliance 

The Site Responsible Engineer/Responsible Engineer - manages and coordinates the implementation of policies and standards relating to integrity of assets

The Site Maintenance Manager - assists with inspection, testing, maintenance and repair of facility assets



For each of the following elements of the site risk management plan, the roles listed have been assigned responsibilities for the development, implementation, and integration of the specific EPA RMP/ OSHA PSM program element (where applicable) as required under Section 68.15 of the RMP rule:



* HAZARD ASSESSMENTS



The PSM Engineer has the responsibility for (1) ensuring that offsite consequence analysis for each regulated process are consistently performed and documented in accordance with Sections 68.20 through 68.39 and (2) selecting the scenarios that will be reported in the facility RMP as required under Section 68.165. The PSM Engineer also is responsible for ensuring that the accident history for each covered process is appropriately documented and maintained in accordance with Section 68.42 and 68.168 of the RMP rule.



* PREVENTION PROGRAMS



The PSM Engineer has the general responsibility for ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant Program 3 prevention program that meets EPA RMP (Sections 68.65 through 68.87 of the RMP rule) and OSHA PSM requirements. Although the PSM Engineer has some specific individual responsibilities, many of the responsibilities for specific program elements are assigned to other positions.



* PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



The responsibility for process safety information (PSI) (Section 68.65 of the RMP rule) is held by the Regional Technology Manager and the Site Responsible Engineer.  The information on the hazards and the technology of the process is the responsibility of the Regional Technology M

anager.  Information on the equipment in the process is the responsibility of the Site Responsible Engineer. 

 

* PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS



In accordance with Section 68.67 of the RMP rule, the Responsible Operating Manager has ultimate responsibility for ensuring that process hazard analysis (PHAs) are scheduled, conducted, and documented by trained personnel for all regulated processes. The Regional Technology Manager selects PHA team leaders and ensures that they receive appropriate training before leading PHAs. Outside contractors may also be used to lead PHAs when appropriate. The Hazard Study Leader is responsible for (1) ensuring that the information and personnel necessary to conduct PHAs are available according to the PHA implementation schedule and (2) resolving recommendations that are assigned to their respective areas.  Recommendation s are assigned and tracked through the Corrective Actions Recordkeeping System (CARS).



* OPERATING PROCEDURES



In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the Responsible Operating Manager has the responsibility for ensuring that complete and accurate operating procedures are in place for all regulated processes. In coordination with the Regional EHS Manager and the Site Maintenance Manager, the Responsible Operating Manager ensures that training is developed and delivered to maintain the facility's safe work practices for both operations and maintenance.



* TRAINING



In accordance with Section 68.71 of the RMP rule, the PSM Engineer in conjunction with the other functional managers have responsibility for (1) ensuring that employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and the associated processes and (2) ensuring that all facility employees receive and understand training in a safe work practices applicable to their jobs and (3) documenting the training. (E.g. The Operations Manager ensures training for operations, the Maintenance Manager addresses training for maintenance w

orkers under the mechanical integrity program, The Technology Director ensures training on Major Accident Hazards for all employees)



* MECHANICAL INTEGRITY



In accordance with Section 68.73 of the RMP rule, the Site Responsible Engineer and Site Maintenance Manager have the responsibility for the overall mechanical integrity program, with specific emphasis on written procedures and maintenance specific training, the equipment and instrumentation inspection/test program and documentation, and equipment deficiency resolution as well as equipment initial design or modifications. Maintenance and Engineering with with Procurement to define and maintain appropriate quality assurance procedures for all types of equipment acquisitions/installations/repairs.



* MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



In accordance with Section 68.75 of the RMP rule, the PSM Engineer has the responsibility for the overall management of change (MOC) program; however, the Responsible Operations Manager has responsibility for final authorization of changes in order to ensure that the overall MOC program is effectively implemented in the process areas.



* PRE-STARTUP REVIEW



In accordance with Section 68.77 of the RMP rule, the PSM Engineer has the responsibility for the overall pre-startup review system, which is integrated into the MOC program. However, the Responsible Operations Manager has the primary responsibility for ensuring that this program is effectively implemented before affected operations begin.



* COMPLIANCE AUDIT



In accordance with Section 68.79 of the RMP rule, the PSM Engineer has the responsibility for ensuring that compliance audits regularly occur (and are documented) to verify that the prevention program is working and meets EPA/OSHA requirements. Each functional leader has responsibility for resolving any identified deficiency in their area.  



* INCIDENT INVESTIGATION



In accordance with Section 68.83 of the RMP rule, the Regional EHS Manager has the responsibility fo

r managing the incident investigation program, including tracking resolution of investigation findings and recommendations. Part of this responsibility is ensuring that only trained personnel lead our investigations. The PSM Engineer will assist with process safety related incidents.  The Operations Manager has primary responsibility for ensuring that all incidents in their areas are reported and investigated, and the investigations findings are resolved, documented, and communicated to affected personnel.



* EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



In accordance with Section 68.83 of the RMP rule, the PSM Engineer, working with the Regional EHS Manager, and Responsible Operating Manager, has the responsibility of involving employees in the planning and implementation of the facility's prevention program elements.



* HOT WORK PERMITS



In accordance with Section 68.85 of the RMP rule, the Site Maintenance Manager, working closely with the Operations Manager and the Regional EHS Manager, have the responsibility of developing and maintaining the facility's hot work permit program.



* CONTRACTORS



In accordance with Section 68.87 of the RMP rule, the Site Maintenance Manager through use of a Contractor Specialist has the overall responsibility for the contractor management program; however, the Regional EHS Manager has responsibility for Contractor training and safety.  The Responsible Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that the requirements of the program are implemented in their areas of responsibility.



* EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



In accordance with Sections 68.90 and 68.95 of the RMP rule, the Regional EHS Manager is responsible for (1) designing, implementing, and maintaining the facility's emergency response plan, (2) ensuring that all associated training and drills are conducted and documented as necessary, (3) coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community emergency response plan, and (4) responding to local emergency planners/resp

onders when questions arise. This includes coordination and communication with the public and community and local emergency agencies. 



* RMPLAN PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION



The PSM Engineer is responsible for preparing and submitting the RMPlan for the facility as required under Sections 68.150 through 68.185 of the RMP rule.



RMPLAN COMMUNICATION



The PSM Engineer and the Regional EHS Manager have the responsibility of providing RMPlan information (other than the required EPA submission) to employees and the public as required under Section 68.210 of the RMP rule.  





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Each year the site is responsible for the development of an EHS improvement plan which includes process safety elements.  Past improvements include to conversion from Trimethyl amine (TMA) to Dimethylamine (DEA) as an inherently safer technology and implementation of storage tank overfill protection.  Future improvements include increased emergency response training for Mitsubishi Chemical employees to allow industrial fire-fighting and confined space rescue, and further implementation of storage tank overfill protection.
